page.title: 07 Barham's Disused Railway.
page.content: The Elham Valley Railway ,from Canterbury to Folkestone, was opened in 1884 and was closed in 1947,when it became uneconomic,due to improved road travel.It followed a winding route passing through Barham.This proved to be very useful during World War II, when the Boche-Buster gun was kept on the line.It had a range of 18 miles,but could fire in all directions if moved along the track.The gun was kept in a tunnel in Bourne Park,which had been built originally because the owner had not wanted to see a railway go through his ground.The "cut and cover" method was used for the tunnel.Barham station was in Heathfield Way,built on the site of the track,which together with Fox Way was named after railway workers who lived in cottages on Railway Hill.The signal box can be seen at Arter Bros. garage on the A2.
